What does it do? These look completely equivalent to me, I would argue that Opposite.rec is better because it has more descriptive parameter names.

import Mathlib

/--
info: Opposite.rec.{u_1, u} {α : Sort u} {motive : αᵒᵖ → Sort u_1} (op : (unop : α) → motive (Opposite.op unop)) (t : αᵒᵖ) :
  motive t
-/
#guard_msgs in
#check Opposite.rec

/--
info: Opposite.rec'.{v, u} {α : Sort u} {F : αᵒᵖ → Sort v} (h : (X : α) → F (Opposite.op X)) (X : αᵒᵖ) : F X
-/
#guard_msgs in
#check Opposite.rec'

It looks like the prime was introduced in #3193, because of the clash with the auto-generated one that was created by making Opposite a structure. It seems to me that we should remove the hand-generated one, and instead mark the auto-generated one simp and induction_eliminator (maybe it already gets that). (By which I mean deprecate .rec' in favour of .rec)
I think that it was introduced for mathport compatibility.
Aaron Liu has marked this topic as resolved.
